div.h1: Optical character recognition of typeset Coptic text with neural networks

div.div:
Collaborative Research Centre 1136 “Education and Religion in Cultures of the Mediterranean and Its Environment from Ancient to Medieval Times and to the Classical Islam,” Seminar for Egyptology and Coptic Studies, and eTRAP Research Group, University of Göttingen,
Germany

Digital Scholarship in the Humanities, Volume 34, Issue Supplement_1, December 2019, Pages i135–i141, https://doi.org/10.1093/llc/fqz023

div.p: So Miyagawa, Kirill Bulert, Marco Büchler, Heike Behlmer, Optical character recognition of typeset Coptic text with neural networks, Digital Scholarship in the Humanities, Volume 34, Issue Supplement_1, December 2019, Pages i135–i141, https://doi.org/10.1093/llc/fqz023

optgroup.label: Search within this journal
optgroup.option: All Digital Scholarship in the Humanities

optgroup.label: Search within this journal
optgroup.option: All Digital Scholarship in the Humanities

section.p: Digital Humanities (DH) within Coptic Studies, an emerging field of development, will be much aided by the digitization of large quantities of typeset Coptic texts. Until recently, the only Optical Character Recognition (OCR) analysis of printed Coptic texts had been executed by Moheb S. Mekhaiel, who used the Tesseract program to create a text model for liturgical books in the Bohairic dialect of Coptic. However, this model is not suitable for the many scholarly editions of texts in the Sahidic dialect of Coptic which use noticeably different fonts. In the current study, DH and Coptological projects based in Göttingen, Germany, collaborated to develop a new Coptic OCR pipeline suitable for use with all Coptic dialects. The objective of the study was to generate a model which can facilitate digital Coptic Studies and produce Coptic corpora from existing printed texts. First, we compared the two available OCR programs that can recognize Coptic: Tesseract and Ocropy. The results indicated that the neural network model, i.e. Ocropy, performed better at recognizing the letters with supralinear strokes that characterize the published Sahidic texts. After training Ocropy for Coptic using artificial neural networks, the team achieved an accuracy rate of >91% for the OCR analysis of Coptic typeset. We subsequently compared the efficiency of Ocropy to that of manual transcribing and concluded that the use of Ocropy to extract Coptic from digital images of printed texts is highly beneficial to Coptic DH.

div.p: For a text to be rendered machine-readable, it must be represented in digital form. There are typically two approaches to converting the textual information inside typeset texts to digital form. Text can be transcribed/typed manually or extracted from the digital image of the document,1 using specialist software. Optical character recognition (OCR) is a computational method of digitally converting typeset documents, handwritten documents, and photos into digitally encoded characters (cf. Schantz 1982). This article is focused on the OCR of typeset Coptic texts, leaving aside, at this point, the OCR of handwritten manuscripts. Despite digital transcription methods having been in development since the 1970s, modern typeset documents with ancient texts still present a significant challenge for OCR technology. These documents possess additional complexities and barriers to automated conversion, due to stains, unfamiliar typefaces, lacunae, unfamiliar punctuation, unfamiliar diacritics, unfamiliar sigla, etc. While manual typing may be a comparatively straightforward option, this method presents a significant challenge to the resources available to Coptologists.

Coptic represents the final stage of the Egyptian language, and is the language of a wide range of literature, both original and translated, including hagiographical, patristic and liturgical texts, Gnostic and Manichaean writings, and magical, scientific, and monastic texts. Coptic, in theory, presents an ideal alphabet for OCR tools, comprising around thirty standard and accented letters, and multiple punctuation marks. However, as Coptic is not currently read, spoken or written by a large community (except for the use of the Bohairic dialect in Coptic Christian liturgies) and mainly of academic interest, there has been little pressure to create OCR software for the language.

This article seeks to compare and contrast existing methods for producing digital transcriptions of typeset Coptic text. Further, it will recommend a process that, through use of existing systems, lessens the manual requirements for Coptic text transcription. Finally, it will discuss and promote personal modelling for general texts and specific documents.

Digital conversion of text comprises three key stages. The first is text pre-processing (e.g. binarization, see He et al., 2005; Gupta et al., 2007), the second is text prediction (using an OCR program), and the third is the correction, or ‘post-processing’, of the OCR output text.

Despite multiple studies into specific OCR challenges (e.g. Kluzner et al., 2009), the first comprehensive review of all three stages was published by Uwe Springmann et al. (2014) with a specific focus on Greek and Latin literature.

Tesseract2 was the first OCR tool used with Coptic texts. Using this tool, Moheb S. Mekhaiel was able to create a base model for the automated transcription of Coptic liturgical texts printed with typeset of the Bohairic dialect (Mekhaiel 2009–2013). Tesseract does, however, presume the scanned typeface to be standard. Despite the software being adjustable for the recognition of new fonts, the creation of an adequate Tesseract model for academic use is unfeasible. For simple printed Coptic works, a suitable model can be achieved. It does, however, produce error-ridden documents if the originals are annotated or contain multiple languages. In the case of modern languages, dictionaries can be used to cross-check documents and to correct these errors. However, in the absence of complete dictionaries, dead languages are harder to correct.

In theory, any character-based text can be transformed by OCR software into a digital representation; text recognition is relatively easily conducted using Ocropy3 (the Python-based version of OCRopus, see Breuel, 2008) or Tesseract. Despite Mekhaiel having presented a Coptic model for Tesseract, this study did not achieve a satisfying output on any digitized typeset document without significant pre-processing.

Besa was a fifth-century Coptic writer and abbot in Upper Egypt. His literary legacy mainly comprises his (literary) correspondence with nuns and monks about matters of monastic life. For experimental purposes, a Coptic-language specialist (So Miyagawa) created a clean version of Karl Heinz Kuhn’s 1956 edition of Letters and Sermons of Besa (Kuhn, 1956), along with a corresponding transcription. Initially, simplified pages (such as Fig. 1) were used to determine the restrictions of trained models. The results achieved using simplified pages demonstrated an optimum character prediction. Stripping a page of all annotations and diacritics is a labour-intensive task; however, this process is not considered viable for routine transcription.
Simplified version (excerpt)
Simplified version (excerpt)

Figures 1 and 2 below show the original typeset document and its simplified version. Figure 2 shows characters and symbols highlighted in grey for removal. Furthermore, unrecognizable or missing characters were transcribed with placeholders represented by dots in the underlying edition. These dots were removed in the ‘simplified’ versions creating gaps. Such gaps are recognized differently by both OCR processors and were accounted for in the accuracy evaluation. In pre-processing, we created three different versions of the images to be scanned by the OCR:
‘original’—As shown in Fig. 2, multilingual, with annotations and supralinear strokes.
‘clean’—Not shown, same as Fig. 1 but supralinear strokes are preserved.
‘simplified’—As shown in Fig. 1, monolingual, without annotations and without supralinear strokes.

img.alt: Original Image (excerpt), grey elements are missing in the simplified version

div.p: Original Image (excerpt), grey elements are missing in the simplified version

img.alt: Original Image (excerpt), grey elements are missing in the simplified version

div.p: Original Image (excerpt), grey elements are missing in the simplified version

Two different methods are required when training Tesseract and Ocropy for Coptic printed text prediction:
Ocropy requires no specific typeface for training and needs only a part transcription, or ground truth. Its neural network then uses this transcription to match the textual characters. A significant weakness in this process is that Ocropy cannot learn from an alphabet alone, as a ground truth. Instead, it requires several sample transcriptions with a typical character frequency of the given language. The training process is recorded by iteration, with Springmann having proposed a minimum of 30,000 iterations.4
Tesseract, in contrast, does require a template typeface and matches identified characters to this reference. This can prove very useful as typefaces will have very few variations within a document. Further typefaces can be added, although text prediction using multiple typeface references will take longer to process. To date, this research has employed Mekhaiel’s original model. It is now beginning to examine the use of characters of various typefaces, to improve output for individual texts.

This study utilized an Ocropy model, with ground truth files comprising circa 5,000 characters. These characters include supralinear strokes, braces, and foreign, non-Coptic characters. For OCR, however, multilingual texts and use of foreign characters are considered highly challenging. Furthermore, stains, poor image quality (e.g. blurred image, poor resolution, etc.), and annotations are also considered complex. For optimum output, specific, less complex versions were created for each source image. To create ‘clean’ ground truth and image files, line numbering and footnote annotations were removed, along with foreign characters, punctuation and other annotations. Finally, all supralinear strokes were removed to create a further, ‘simplified,’ ground truth file (Fig. 1).

The selected Coptic source files were then transcribed, with Ocropy referencing the ‘original’ (Fig. 2), ‘clean,’ and ‘simplified’ (Fig. 1) ground truth files. Each output file was subsequently compared with ‘Ocreval’5 with reference to its ground truth.

As Fig. 3 shows, while Mekhaiel’s Tesseract model provided a superior character accuracy of <95% on simplified source files, the new Ocropy model provided a better output on more complex files. However, transcription errors caused by the Tesseract model are often predictable, with, for example, the letter shai always represented as the letter omega. In contrast, Ocropy produces no such errors.
div.h3: 5.2 Project management efficiency in digital Coptic processing
div.p: Each page of manual transcription requires an average of 10 minutes for typing and 10 minutes for proofreading. As such, from a project management perspective, Coptic OCR processing offers significant advantages in terms of cost-saving and efficiency. While many Coptic texts have been published, there are no digital versions other than those published by Coptic digital projects such as Coptic SCRIPTORIUM (Schroeder and Zeldes, 2016), CoptOT,6 Papyri.info,7 Institut für Neutestamentliche Textforschung,8 Marcion,9 the Packard Humanities Institute,10 St Shenouda the Archimandrite Coptic Society,11 Corpus dei Manoscritti Copti Letterari,12 and Sahidica13 or privately by scholars such as Wolf–Peter Funk and by several members of the Coptic community. In fact, Coptic SCRIPTORIUM, the largest digital project for annotated Coptic texts, used the OCR suite created in this study to process Apophthegmata Patrum texts edited by Marius Chaîne (Chaîne, 1960). The model created on the Apophthegmata Patrum is now available on the GitHub repository of the KELLIA project (https://github.com/KELLIA/CopticOCR/tree/master/ApophthegmataPatrum; also see the homepage of the KELLIA project, http://kellia.uni-goettingen.de/). Furthermore, this study also generated digital versions of manuscripts from the Bohairic translation of the Minor Prophets (Tattam, 1836), which is now available on https://github.com/KELLIA/CopticOCR/tree/master/MinorProphetsBohairic.

This study was unable to accurately calculate the time taken to extract an image typeface for Tesseract’s training process, due to limited data available. Ocropy models require initial human input by way of ground truth creation. Its training does not, however, require any further human interaction, although it does consume up to two days of CPU power (Core i3/5 2.4GHz/3.2GHz, 8GB RAM, SSD). Predictions require manual proofreading, which also takes up to 10 minutes per page with 33 lines on average. Figure 4 demonstrates an interpolation of optimal workload reduction using the two OCR tools contrasted with initial manual transcription workload. These calculations are based on the use of source files labeled as ‘clean.’ A more representative scenario is discussed below.

img.alt: OCR accuracy according to text complexity: our comparisons between Mekhaiel’s Tesseract model and our new Ocropy model

div.p: OCR accuracy according to text complexity: our comparisons between Mekhaiel’s Tesseract model and our new Ocropy model

img.alt: OCR accuracy according to text complexity: our comparisons between Mekhaiel’s Tesseract model and our new Ocropy model

div.p: OCR accuracy according to text complexity: our comparisons between Mekhaiel’s Tesseract model and our new Ocropy model
Workload comparison
Workload comparison

As Fig. 3 indicates, the results of this study highlight that, when using simplified source files, Tesseract outperforms Ocropy in terms of accuracy and workload reduction. In more representative circumstances, however, source files will invariably contain some of the above-mentioned complexities; pre-processing is, therefore, crucial for achieving more accurate results. Figure 4 uses the second and third lines from the top to demonstrate more realistic circumstances, with a greater pre-processing workload when using Tesseract. This calculation demonstrates that the time taken for initial setup of an Ocropy model will be compensated when working on larger, more complex documents.

Tesseract’s key benefit is that by utilizing Mekhaiel’s models no training is required, but the most accurate results are only achieved with monolingual unannotated inputs. However, while creation and testing of a new model can be more time-consuming than manual transcription, so too can the creation of clean images, even if the model is reusable. An Ocropy setup can therefore be more efficient on bigger datasets without the need of annotation removal beforehand. The workload is seen to be reduced by up to 50%.

Unicode ambiguities (Unicode Consortium 2017) unfortunately cause issues with text encoding, and need regulation and filtering beforehand if multilingual data is to be processed. Ambiguities such as the Roman numeral (‘XII’: U + 216B) which can be decomposed into a Roman numeral ten (‘X’: U + 2169) and two Roman numeral ones (‘I’: U + 2160), can cause problems if used together in one dataset. Were they not filtered, such encoding issues would not be recognized by humans, and would be overlooked during proofreading. In multilingual texts in particular, such ambiguity can cause characters from pages with different codes to be easily confused. As such, this study recommends that only pages of matching code are processed together. This is especially recommended in the case of multilingual models, to which future work will devote more attention.

While OCR processing of Coptic text remains a complex matter, the present study has shown that the transcription workload for Coptic texts can be reduced through use of an OCR tool. It has also demonstrated that even our ‘simplified’ source text could not be predicted with complete accuracy. As such, improved output quality will rely upon enhanced pre- and post-processing.

Other than Mekhaiel’s, no Coptic OCR models are publicly available. Owing to the fact that large workloads can be significantly reduced through Coptic OCR, this study strongly recommends the publishing of models alongside their corresponding transcriptions, and argues that almost all well-preserved typeset texts could be encoded using OCR software. While the model created for this research was partly successful in recognizing multilingual documents, such as Coptic and English, additional work in this area is recommended. In general, multilingual texts demand specific training processes to ensure optimum accuracy. This is also partially true for Coptic text editions, since a small proportion of the text may contain non-Coptic vocabulary such as Latin, Greek, English, French, or German, especially in footnotes or on margins.
Finally, the trained models which we generated through the process described above are available online on our GitHub repository (https://github.com/KELLIA/CopticOCR) with CC BY-SA 4.0 license.

This work was supported by National Endowment of Humanities/German Research Foundation (DFG) Bilateral Digital Humanities Program within the project KELLIA (the Koptische/Coptic Electronic Language and Literature International Alliance) [NEH: grant number HG-229371-15, DFG: Projektnummer 273503199], eTRAP (electronic Text Reuse Acquisition Project) Early Career Research Group funded by the German Federal Ministry of Education and Research (BMBF) [no. 01UG1509] and German Research Foundation (DFG) Collaborative Research Centre 1136 “Education and Religion in Cultures of the Mediterranean and Its Environment from Ancient to Medieval Times and to the Classical Islam.”
We are grateful to Lloyd Abercrombie, Laura Slaughter, and Julien Delhez for proofreading this article.
1 Here, ‘documents’ denote texts to be OCRed.
2 Tesseract OCR, available at https://github.com/tesseract-ocr (accessed 30 December 2017).

3 Ocropy, available at https://github.com/tmbdev/ocropy (accessed 30 December 2017). Eliese-Sophia Lincke (Humboldt-Universität zu Berlin) has also been working on Ocropy for Coptic typeset texts with a different font.
4 Recommendation made by Uwe Springmann in private conversation, based upon his own experience.

5 OCR Evaluation Tools by Ryan Baumann. Accessible at https://github.com/ryanfb/ancientgreekocr-ocr-evaluation-tools (accessed 1 November 2016). This program calculates the accuracy rate of OCR software comparing the result data of OCR with the ground truth file.

6 The Digital Edition of the Coptic Old Testament is a long-term project at the Göttingen Academy of Sciences and Humanities led by Heike Behlmer and Frank Feder. http://coptot.manuscriptroom.com/ (accessed 30 December 2017). See Behlmer and Feder (2017).
7 Papyri.info contains digital transcription of Coptic papyri and ostraca. http://papyri.info/ (accessed 31 December 2017).

8 The database of Sahidic Biblical texts set up by Christian Askeland and Matthias Schulz at this institute is also available at the CrossWire Bible Society, see http://www.crosswire.org/study/fulllibrary.jsp?show=SahidicBible (accessed 26 January 2019). The New Testament Virtual Manuscript Room provides digital transcriptions of manuscripts containing Coptic translations of books of the New Testament.
9 A digital transcription of the Sahidic translation of the New Testament produced by the Packard Humanities Institute in 1991, which was edited by David Brakke.
10 See Konvicka (2009–16). The digital transcriptions of Coptic texts in this software have some errors but they are being modified.
11 See Takla (2006).
12 See Orlandi (1990).
13 The version of the Packard Humanities Institute was used as a base text for J. Warren Wells’ edition of the Sahidic New Testament, called Sahidica (2000–08).
